Problem:
Consider the mathematical system where a complex function \\( z(t) \\) evolves based on the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = iAz \\), where \\( A \\) is a real number, and \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit. We analyze the effect of a Fourier transform defined as \\( F(z) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-i\\omega t}z(t) \\, dt \\).

If \\( F(z) \\) is applied to a function \\( z(t) = e^{iAt} \\) without any further manipulation, will the resulting transform \\( F(z) \\) at frequency \\( \\omega \\) be localized at \\( \\omega = A \\)?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of \\( z(t) = e^{iAt} \\) is indeed a delta function centered at \\( A \\), \\( F(z) = 2\\pi \\delta(\\omega - A) \\) due to the properties of the Fourier transform of exponential oscillatory functions. This precisely aligns the frequency component with \\( A \\), showcasing direct correspondence.
